_exec_summary.SummaryText:
2.1.1	INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES
The Placid Refining Company LLC  Port Allen Refinery (Placid) is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Placids management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Environmental, Health, Safety and Process Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

2.1.2	STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Port Allen Refinery is operated by Placid Refining Company LLC and processes and refines crude oil to produce products such as gasoline, diesel, LPG, and other petroleum-based products.  The facility is a semi-complex refinery with a Nelson Complexity Factor of 8.7.

The facility consists of several different process units which include Crude, FCC, Rose, CGHT, Treater, Reformer and Naphtha Hydrotreater, HF Alkylation, HDS Treater 2, Vacuum and Jet Fuel, Cryo, Hot Oil, and Storage.

There are two EPA RMP regulated toxic chemicals used at the facility, which are hydrogen fluoride and hydrogen sulfide.  Hydrogen fluoride / Hydrofluoric acid (HF) is the only RMP regulated toxic material present in amounts greater than the threshold quantity.  There are twenty-four RMP regulated flammable materials present as pure components, or in mixtures, in amounts greater than the threshold quantities, that are used or stored at the Placid facility.  Refer to Section 1.17 of Table 3 and Appendix A for a summary of these reg

ulated flammable substances.  The facilitys covered processes meet Program Level Three requirements.

2.1.3	ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Environmental protection, health and safety of employees and contractors, accidental release prevention and emergency response preparedness are core values at Placid and as such are considered in all decision making.   These core values include: 
	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
	Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that the risk of unintentional releases are minimized.
	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that promotes the health and safety of all employees, contractors , and visitors. 
	Continuously striving to improve.

In addition, the following specific programs are in place:

Employee Participation
Placid and contract employees are involved in all aspects of the Process Safety Management Program as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(c) and 40 CFR 68.83.  Placid employees are kept apprised of Process Safety Management issues through various means of communication. Placids Portal System allows employees to access operational manuals, SDS, safety procedures, and emergency procedures. Placid Learning Management System is Exxtend Learn.  This system is used to provide computer-based employee training and manage training documentation.  It is available twenty four hours per day and is updated regularly by Placids Training Department.  The Port Allen Refinery has been an OSHA Star Site since 2006.  In addition, Placid has a VPP Employee Safety Committee that meets weekly. Employee/VPP Safety Meetings are comprised of members from all departments, including contract employees. The suggestions from VPP meetings are posted on the Placid Portal, work orders are written and are tracked to completion. Employees can also access other important safety announcements and information via the Placid Portal.  Safety-related information i

s also communicated during the supervisor safety meetings every other month. Supervisors are asked to pass along this information to their employees. Placids MOC process requires interdepartmental involvement, which ensures that engineering and supervisory level employees have knowledge of the change.  Safety Meetings are held on a periodic basis for all operations, maintenance, laboratory, terminal, administration, and contract personnel. Bulletin boards are positioned throughout the refinery and are used for communication.  Safety suggestions and concerns can be reported directly to Placid Safety personnel or through employee safety committee representatives.  Safety specific work orders can be generated by employees in the Maximo system and are tracked to completion by maintenance and safety personnel.  Near-misses can be submitted through an online submission system and are investigated by area supervisors.  Employees can access near-miss and incident investigation information on the Placid Portal at any time.  All employees, including nested contract employees, are encouraged to participate in Placids safety program through the use of a point-based incentive program (CASH Rewards); this program rewards employees for reporting or resolving safety concerns, as well as other safety related activities.

Top-Down safety audits are performed quarterly and are used to encourage open communication between management and front-line employees. During these audits, members of management make field visits to different areas of the refinery.  Employees assigned to the area are encouraged to participate in the audit and are asked to share ideas on how to make the refinery a safer place to work. Any safety concerns discovered during these audits are immediately resolved when possible; work orders are generated when the concern cannot be resolved without maintenance involvement. 

Peak Performance Drills are performed on shift by operations personnel. Each drill is a scripte

d rehearsal for a particular scenario, such as a power failure, equipment failure, leak, fire, etc. The scenario is selected by the area supervisor, and can include one area, or multiple areas, of the refinery. This training creates the confidence needed to respond and react appropriately during an actual emergency. Critical Task Drills, developed by supervisors on each shift, involve a high-risk routine task in which the supervisor walks through the procedure with frontline workers. This scenario is sent to the Training Department where it can be compared to existing procedures; procedures are modified or developed as needed. The Critical Task Drill is then sent out to all shifts, where it is then reviewed with all affected employees.

Process Safety Information
Placid makes Process Safety Information (PSI) readily available to all employees as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(d) and 40 CFR 68.65.  Placid keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  Specific departments within Placid are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date PSI. 

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets.  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals, especially if they are incompatible or mixed product bring new hazards to the operation.  For specific process areas, Placid has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (i.e., temperature, level, composition) in the operation manuals for each process unit.  Placid ensures that the process is maintained within these limits by using process co

ntrols and monitoring instruments, operating procedures, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (i.e., automated shutdown systems). 

Placid also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Placid also recognizes that 89 Federal Register 17622 (March 11, 2024) Risk Management Programs under the Clean Air Act; Safer Communities by Chemical Accident Prevention has implications for this facility as well.  The finalized rule has several implementation dates associated with various parts of the new/updated regulation.  However, at the time of this resubmittal, Placid interprets that 40 CFR §68.65(d)(2) - before conducting a PHA, compile PSI and ensure and document compliance with RAGAGEP to be imposed at the refinery by May 10, 2024.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) 
Placid conducts a Process Hazard Analysis for all process units, tank farm piping, truck rack, MVRU, and storage tanks every five years as required by 29 CFR 1910.119 and 40 CFR 68.67.  Placids PHAs are performed using the HAZOP (Hazard and Operability Analysis) methodology.  Placid contracts a third party PSM expert to assist the HAZOP Team in performing the HAZOP process.  The HAZOP Team is comprised of employees from various departments, including an Operator from the area that is being assessed, and one representative each from the I & E, and Engineering Departments.

The information compiled from the HAZOP is reviewed bi-monthly by the HAZOP Recommendation Review Team, which includes all Placid proc

ess engineers, VPP/Safety Coordinator, Health and Safety Compliance Specialist, Emergency Response, Safety, and Security Team Leader, Training Coordinator, Training Manager, Process Superintendent, Operations Manager, Terminal Superintendent, Tech Services Manager, Reliability Manager, Maintenance Superintendent, Health, Safety, and Environmental Manager, Maintenance Engineering Superintendent, Operations Manager, and Vice President of Refining. 

Each HAZOP recommendation is ranked, and the HAZOP Recommendation Review Team decides whether to proceed with the recommendation or cancel the recommendation.  Each cancelled recommendation is signed by the Vice President of Refining, a Safety representative, and the Operations Manager, a Closure Status From is filled out, the justification for cancelling the recommendation is documented, and the recommendation is filed in the Safety Department by unit or area.  Recommendations that are approved are evaluated through the MOC process,  sent out for review, and all affected employees are trained on the recommendation by CBT, or by their supervisor.  These recommendations are documented, and a written schedule is developed to track the recommendations to completion.  Once a recommendation is complete, a Completion From is signed by a Safety representative and kept on file in the Safety Department.  All affected employees are required to review these recommendations, and all training is documented.  Both approved recommendations and closed recommendations are posted on the Placid Portal where they can be easily accessed by all employees. 
All new process HAZOPs are complete PHAs and meet all requirements on 29 CFR 1910.119(e) and 40 CFR 68.67.  Thereafter, every other five-year cycle, Placid alternates between conducting Redos and Revalidations.  Redos, are complete, new PHAs which meet the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119(e) and 40 CFR 68.67.  A Revalidation confirms that a PHA accurately reflects the process hazar

ds given the current equipment configuration, process operations, staffing and surroundings, and that the analysis meets the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119(e) and 40 CFR 68.67. 

Placid recognizes that 89 Federal Register 17622 (March 11, 2024) Risk Management Programs under the Clean Air Act; Safer Communities by Chemical Accident Prevention has implications for this facility as well.  The finalized rule has several implementation dates associated with various parts of the new/updated regulation.  At the time of this resubmittal, Placid interprets the following items to be imposed at the refinery by May 10, 2024:


o	Evaluate risk posed by natural hazards, power loss, and facility siting for covered process units (40 CFR 68.67(c)(5) and (8)).
o	Ensure monitoring equipment associated with prevention and detection of accidental releases from covered processes has standby or backup power (40 CFR §68.67(c)(3)).
o	Identify any gaps in safety between the codes and standards to which the process was designed and constructed and the most current versions of applicable codes and standards (40 CFR §68.67(c)(10)).

Placid also performs What-If surveys on MOC work that is considered to be safety critical.  This includes any project or work that would significantly alter the process or could ultimately result in the catastrophic release of a Highly Hazardous Chemical as defined in 29 CFR 1910.119.  These What-If Analyses are informal, scaled down versions of our normal PHAs, and are conducted prior to instituting the change.  A small team is formed, usually including representatives from the operations, engineering, and Safety departments.  Possible effects of the change are reviewed by the team, and it is determined whether the work should continue as planned or if a full PHA is needed.

Operating Procedures
Placids Operating Procedures cover all aspects of process unit operation including initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, controlled shutdowns,

and emergency shutdowns as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(f) and 40 CFR 68.69. Operating Procedures and Unit Manuals are reviewed annually and updated if needed.  Operating limits, as well as safety and health information, are included in these documents.  These documents are also updated immediately when warranted by an MOC change and to include new equipment.  The review process is done by certified individuals; however, the Unit Supervisor is responsible for making sure all documents assigned are reviewed and must approve any changes before they are made.  Once the review is complete, the information is forwarded to the Training Department where the manuals are updated, and the changes are posted on the Placid Portal.  Latest changes/additions are highlighted in yellow for ease of reference and will remain highlighted until a new change is made.  At that time, the previous highlighted will be removed from the text.  A hard copy of the unit manuals is located in the control room along with a binder containing a hard copy of the emergency procedures for each unit.  All manuals and procedures are also available electronically on the Placid Portal . In addition, backup hard copies of the unit manuals are available in the Training Department.  All Training Department personnel have 25 plus years of service with Placid Refining Company, which includes field and DCS experience.  These individuals have thorough knowledge of the equipment and systems used by the industry and incorporate this experience to improve procedure and manual integrity.

Training
Placids employee training program meets all requirements set forth by 29 CFR 1910.119(g) and 40 CFR 68.71.  Training of refinery and contract personnel is an on-going process.  All process operators and OMTs (terminal operators) initially undergo an intensive four-year training program to receive certification. Employees must achieve certification on each process unit/area for which they will be responsible and must recerti

fy every three years following their initial certification date. Process and Terminal Operators must complete refresher training every three (3) years on unit procedures as required by PSM. 
Operators are surveyed as to their preference for additional refresher training frequency.  Operators must also be trained on any changes to the process brought about by MOCs.  New maintenance personnel and contractors are shown a process overview video so that they have at least awareness level knowledge of the process, and any hazards related to the process. In addition, all maintenance personnel are trained on the specific areas in which they will be working.  Safety training is conducted throughout the year for all Placid employees, and all contract employees.  Visitors to the site are provided with basic safety information through a short orientation prior to entry.  This orientation covers information such as the emergency notification system, safety rules, and assembly point locations.

Contractors 
Placids contractor program meets all requirements established by 29 CFR 1910.119(h) and 40 CFR 68.87. Contractors are screened and their safety performance is evaluated before they are allowed to work on site.  Each potential contractor must send in a PQF or Pre-Qualification From.  These forms are reviewed by Placids Safety Department personnel to determine whether the contractor meets the minimum requirements to perform work for Placid.  Factors such as the companys last three years safety performance, OSHA 300 logs, Total Recordable Incident Rate, and Experience Modifier Rate, are considered during this review process.  If the company does not meet the minimum requirements but is the only viable option to perform the required work, those workers may be allowed into the facility under certain conditions/stipulations set forth by the Health, Safety, and Environmental Manager.  For example, the company may be required to provide its own on-site safety professional, and th

at person would be required to be always present at the job site.  Any contract company with more than twenty-five employees working in the refinery is required to provide an on-site safety professional. 

Contractors are shown a safety orientation video and are required to take a quiz following the video.  The video addresses refinery safety procedures, job permitting, drug and alcohol policy, smoking restrictions, confined space, hot work, refinery speed limits, harassment, personnel protective equipment, dress code, footwear requirements, hearing conservation program, employee notification system, and an overview of the process units in the plant.  The Safety and Training Departments conduct additional training for the contractors as necessary or appropriate.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
Placid utilizes a Pre-Startup Safety Review program which consists of a check list and signed documentation that must be completed prior to startup of a unit or process equipment (MOC) change. This program is in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119(i) and 40 CFR 68.77.  Placids Pre-Startup Safety Review Process allows Operations/Terminal, Engineering, Safety/Training, and Maintenance to review the change to ensure that all equipment is in place, repairs or installations have been completed, training has been completed, materials of construction meet specification standards, housekeeping is complete, and all safeguards are in place.  Once the documentation is complete, it will be placed with the project file along with drawings and other project information, and the change can then be put into service.


Mechanical Integrity
Placids mechanical integrity program is an integral part of our daily operations.  It is in compliance with the regulations set forth in 29 CFR 1910.119(j) and 40 CFR 68.73.  Inspections are done on equipment and piping that are on-line and during unit turnarounds.  The inspection documents are collected and saved in an equipment condition tracking software

called PCMS.  This software also has the ability to track corrosion rates and to identify any problem areas.  After each turnaround, an inspection report is issued as to the condition of equipment, piping, and vessels.  This information is also available on the Placid Portal.  Mechanical inspection is an on-going process as whenever lines are opened up, flanges and piping are inspected.  The Inspection Department also sets schedules for inspections on storage tanks.  Files are kept up to date with current information based on relevant codes and industry standards. Monthly inspection reports are mailed out to each department manager and are discussed in the monthly Managers Safety Committee meeting.

Hot Work Permits
Placids Hot Work Permits meet the fire prevention and protection requirements for Hot Work Permits as mandated by 29 CFR 1910.252(a) and 40 CFR 68.85.  Placid personnel issue a Hot Work Permit any time hot work is to take place.  As per Placids Hot Work Procedure (SP-09), gas monitoring is required prior to hot work beginning, and in certain instances, continuous LEL monitoring is required.  Hot work can include, but is not limited to, welding, cutting, brazing, gouging, use of battery operated tools, and vehicle entry in certain areas of the refinery.  Placid employees and contract employees are retrained annually on the hot work procedure.  Any new contract employee entering the refinery for the first time must attend our site specific orientation.  This orientation video covers the use of Hot Work Permits in the refinery.  The Safety Department randomly audits Hot Work Permits in the field to ensure correctness.  Beginning on April 30th, 2024, each Hot Work Permit is kept in the field until the corresponding job has been completed, but will be retained for three years per 89 FR 17691, March 11, 2024 (40 CFR 68.96(c)).

Management of Change (MOC)
Placids Management of Change (MOC) Program complies with 29 CFR 1910.119(l) and 40 CFR 68.75.  A chang

e is defined as anything repaired or replaced that is not a replacement in kind, or any change in the way the process is operated or supervised.  Placid presently uses the Gateway MOC Software to track all proposed MOCs and working MOCs.  New MOCs are entered into the Gateway system by Process/ Mechanical Engineering.

Emergency MOCs (EMOCs) can be generated by Terminal and Operations supervision, as well as Process Engineering.  Once created, the MOC must follow the progression listed in Section XXIII (Management of Change Program) section of Placids Process Safety Management (PSM) Manual.

Incident Investigation
Placids Incident Investigation Procedure (SP44) is in compliance with 29 CFR 1910.119(m) and 40 CFR 68.81.  An incident investigation is required for an employee injury/accident, equipment failure, loss of product containment, fire, explosion, and in some cases, near-misses. The initial incident investigation report should be filed electronically within 12 hours.  All incidents are reported using the electronic Incident Management program on the Placid Portal.  All personnel responsible for investigating incidents have been trained on Root Cause Analysis through a third-party instructor.  The Training Manager conducts a formal incident investigation any time an incident involves a fire, injury, or fatality.  All other incidents are investigated by the Training Manager, or a designee.  The individual in charge of the incident investigation is responsible for meeting with employees involved in the incident, collecting documents to help determine root cause, following up on recommendations and witness statements, assigning tasks and target dates, and tracking tasks to completion.  Any contract companies involved in an incident must be involved in the incident investigation process.  Once all recommendations/ tasks have been completed, the formal investigation report is signed by the Vice President of Refining to close out the incident investigation.  The

signed report is filed in the Safety Department, and the final findings of the investigation can be accessed by all employees on the Placid Portal.  Incidents and near-misses are discussed in weekly safety meetings, including contractor safety meetings.

Emergency Planning and Response
Placid has an established emergency action plan as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(n) and 40 CFR 68.95.  This plan can be found in the Emergency Procedure Manual or electronically on the Placid Portal.  PRC has trained Emergency Response Team members on each shift.  All Emergency Response Team members are equipped with personal bunker gear and receive annual training.  Placid Refining Company has employees trained in confined space rescue, emergency, and medical response on each shift.  Emergency drills are performed annually, and communication with the I-Notification system allows both Placid and local community emergency responders to stay abreast should a potential emergency develop.

Compliance Audits
Placid Refining Company conducts compliance audits on a scheduled basis (every 3 years) as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(o) and 40 CFR 68.79.  Once a compliance audit has been conducted, the audit results are made available to all employees for review on the Placid Portal.  These audits are generally conducted by a third-party company, and all recommendations are evaluated and considered by Placid Management. Accepted recommendations are tracked by the Safety Department to ensure their completion.  Both Placid and contract employees participate in these audits through employee interviews.

Trade Secrets
Placid Refining Company has several units in the refinery that were designed by other companies.  Certain information related to the design of these units is required by those companies to be kept confidential. However, the mechanical integrity program, employee training, and safe work practices in these units are the same as for all our other process units.  All information necessary for

unit operation, PHAs, incident investigation, emergency planning and response, and compliance audits is made readily available to all involved personnel as required by 29 CFR 1910.119(p).
?
2.1.4	PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Placid Facility is operating under the standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Management and employee commitment to ongoing analysis of the potential hazards of the process, detailed training, and emphasis on safety have prevented serious chemical release accidents over the last 5 years.  Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to reduce the risk of potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:
	Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels, piping, pumps, control systems and safety systems through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
	Vessels and storage tanks are protected from overpressure with pressure relief devices or conservation vents.
	Vessels containing flammable materials predominately vent to a flare gas recovery system for safe destruction. 
	Process conditions are monitored from a control room where alarms warn trained personnel of abnormal operating conditions.
	Secondary containment is available in the form of dikes and drain sumps.

2.1.5	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Within the last five years, there have been no releases of RMP Regulated Substances that resulted in onsite injuries, death or property damage or any offsite impacts.

2.1.6	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the local Port Allen Fire Department, West Baton Rouge Parish Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), Acadian Ambulance, Baton Rouge General Burn Unit (for HF acid medical treatment),

Baton Rouge Area Mutual Aid System, North Baton Rouge Industry Task Force, E3 OMI Oil Spill Removal Organization (OSRO), U.S. Coast Guard, Louisiana State Police, and Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) HAZMAT.  As appropriate, also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the Louisiana State Police, National Response Center (NRC), and other coordinating agencies, and local hospitals.  The Refinery Shift Supervisor or Incident Commander is responsible for coordinating emergency actions depending on the severity and scale of an incident.  A specific Emergency Response Plan (Emergency Procedures Manual) for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials.  The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

2.1.7	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Compliance with the RMP Prevention Program forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components of the safety program are:
	The Management of Change (MOC) provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, equipment, or procedures are considered.
	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards.
	The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.

Specific actions at the Placid Refinery that will be taken in the future to improve the level of safety at the facility include:
	Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements.
	An ongoing dialogue wit

h Port Allen Fire Department and other outside agencies will ensure a constant state of readiness to respond to any potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.  The facility coordinates its response capabilities and personnel with those of the parish on an ongoing basis.
	Involvement in OSHA Special Government Employee (SGE) program, and OSHA Voluntary Protection Program (VPP).
	Continued participation in industry specific work groups for knowledge sharing purposes.  Work group membership includes: AFPM Health & Safety Committee, Greater Baton Rouge Industry Alliance, AFPM Eastern Gulf Coast Occupational Safety Regional Network, AFPM Process Safety Regional Network, AFPM Gulf Coast HF Alky Operations Regional Network, West Baton Rouge LEPC, Baton Rouge Area Mutual Aid System (BRAMAS), LMOGA and LDEQ focus groups.
